abstract_summ: This three-fold risk of harm to which marginalized persons are subjected runs counter to the very notion of social justice that underpins public health.We argue that public officials should make efforts to inform and persuade the public of the importance of social distancing, targeting mediums like TV and radio where audiences are less likely to currently engage in social distancing or are less likely to envision themselves sustaining strict social distancing for several weeks or months.In other words, marginalized or disadvantaged persons are at risk of both contracting SARS-CoV-2 and the risk of harms that may come about because of the social distancing measures themselves.Although unprecedented in scope and beyond all our life experiences, sweeping social distancing measures are not without historical precedent.Who are the individuals who are the least likely to adhere to social distancing recommendations, presently and in the long‐term?
